results.title: Battle for Australia
results.creator_credit: Jean King and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: I have vivid memories of watching the Army march along Swanston Street, fit and tanned with heads held high, wearing the famous slouch hat. Jean King’s husband was a navy salvage diver during World War II, and she shares her experiences of being the wife of a war veteran as well as the toll the war took on families and the returned after the war

results.title: All the days of my life
results.creator_credit: Joan Johnstone and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: In 1941, the Australian Women’s Army Services was formed and Joan chose to join the AWAS to fight for Australia. Her dad was in the army as was missing in action. Joan was transferred to work on Salt, the official army publication. It was called Salt because salt was so essential to life. Joan’s story is about her service, her marriage and her work with Salt.

results.title: Fanny and Alexander
results.creator_credit: Ingmar Bergman, Jorn Donner, Tobis Filmkunst, Personafilm, Gaumont-British Instructional and Cinematograph for Svenska Filminstitutet
results.brief_description: An edited version dubbed in English. Told through the eyes of a small boy, this most personal of Bergman’s works is both autobiographical and an artistic reference point. Set during the turn-of-the century Sweden, the story is about the well-to-do, loving and ebullient Ekdahl family. When the actor-father of 10 year old Alexander and 8 year old Fanny dies, their mother marries a sadistic minister. His cruelty leads Grandmother Eckdahl’s Jewish friend and lover to rescue them. Happiness and balance is restored. Announced as Bergman’s final film, it offers a superlative culmination of his 37 years as one of cinema’s greatest artists. Oscar Winner 1982 for Best Foreign Language Film, Best Cinematography, Best Art Direction and Best Costume Design. Stars Pernilla Allwin, Bertil Guve, Ewa Froling, Jan Malmsjo, Erland Josephson.

results.title: Families get angry
results.creator_credit: Delton Cook, John Simons and Oxford Films (U.S.)
results.brief_description: A family quarrel begins when the father in a black, low-income family is trying to stretch too little money to pay too many bills. The two children are strongly affected by their parents’ conflict.

results.title: Falling from ladders
results.creator_credit: Mort Ransen, Joseph Koenig, Tom Daly, John Kemeny, National Film Board of Canada and Svenska filminstitutet
results.brief_description: Simply by putting about twenty Swedish men, women and young people in front of his camera and having them read aloud from the Statistical Year Book, filmmaker Mort Ransen has recorded a wide range of impressions of Sweden’s economic and social existence. Quotations vary from the whole gamut of exports and imports, marriages formed or dissolved, to the number of people who fall from ladders annually.

results.title: Family tree
results.creator_credit: Evelyn Lambart, George Dunning, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The story of the settlement of Canada, illustrated with cheerful animated cartoons. The arrival of Jacques Cartier, the fishing and fur trades which followed, and the rival colonization by the French and British, climaxed by the battle of the Plains of Abraham, are depicted. The coming of the United Empire Loyalists is seen; then the west-coast gold rush and the completion of the transcontinental railway. New branches were added to the family tree when many European settlers came to fill the great spaces of the Prairies. Finally, we see the whole country matured into a nation, its traditions enriched by those of many peoples.

results.title: Upstairs downstairs
results.creator_credit: Donna Swan, Steve Thomas and Flying Carpet Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Family foibles”.
Part of the “Family foibles” series of documentaries about five Australian families. “Upstairs downstairs” explores Harald’s and Louise’s attempt to deal with the break-up of their 14-year relationship which occurred during the first year of their daughter Sophia’s life. Both wanted to maintain a sense of family and home for Sophia without inflicting their personal conflict onto her by staying together ‘for the sake of the children’. Their solution was to convert their house into two self-contained living areas with separate entrances, an arrangement that allows minimal disruption to Sophia’s life. Both parents work full-time and share parenting through a 50:50 roster that has room for some flexibility. The daily workings of this social experiment are observed as the two negotiate the challenges of having a ‘single but equal’ approach to parenting, while living seperately in close proximity to one another. A study guide is available from http://www.roninfilms.com.au/related/2365104851-0.pdf

results.title: Kim and Harley and the kids
results.creator_credit: Katrina Sawyer, Steve Thomas and Flying Carpet Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Family foibles”.
Part of the “Family foibles” series of documentaries about five Australian families. Kim and Harley are an impoverished couple living in a Ministry of Housing estate in outer Melbourne with their four little girls, including their 4-year old twins and 12-year old Gabby, the eldest, Kim’s child from an earlier marriage. By pawning their possessions, selling scrap metal and accepting food donations from charity organisations, they barely manage to make ends meet. Their circumstances are made more difficult by the fact that Kim suffers from hepatitis C and high levels of stress. While the family demonstrates great resourcefulness, humour and patience to survive below the poverty line, their hardships cause tensions to erupt regularly into aggressive shouting matches which occasionally become physically violent. A confronting portrait of a family with no support which confounds all simplistic explanations of poverty. A study guide is available from http://www.roninfilms.com.au/related/2365104851-0.pdf
results.creator_credit_for_label: Katrina Sawyer, Steve Thomas and Flying Carpet Films

results.title: My mother Nancy
results.creator_credit: Veronica Iacono, Steve Thomas and Flying Carpet Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Family foibles”.
Part of the “Family foibles” series of documentaries about five Australian families. Having had a traditional Italian Catholic immigrant upbringing in Sydney, marrying when her parents wanted her to and raising a family of three (including her daughter, Veronica, the director of this documentary), Nancy decides to break away from the traditional expectations of her marriage and, without consulting her husband, opens a cafe with a friend. Three years later, at age fifty, she is estranged from her sisters, who criticise her bid for independence and from her husband, who refuses to set foot in the cafe. While she still lives with, and cooks for her husband, they no longer talk to each other. Through a sensitive but persistent investigation of her mum’s predicament, Veronica unveils the guilt, anxiety, grief and regret, which pervade Nancy’s soul as she presses ahead with her business ambitions. She also unravels the tangle of generational, cultural and religious attitudes in which her diminutive but spirited mother is caught. A study guide is available from http://www.roninfilms.com.au/related/2365104851-0.pdf
results.creator_credit_for_label: Veronica Iacono, Steve Thomas and Flying Carpet Films

results.title: Mick's gift
results.creator_credit: Celeste Geer, Steve Thomas and Flying Carpet Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Family foibles”.
Part of the “Family foibles” series of five documentaries about Australian families. Filmmaker Celeste Geer takes as her starting point a box of long forgotten 16mm amateur film shot by her late grandfather Mick in the 1940s and 1950s, in an attempt to better understand the character of the man she idolised as a child. She found that the memories captured in the footage of his family, friends and travels and the those that emerged through the recollections of family members and an old mate, offered up contradictory images of her grandfather which challenged the mythology around him built up in her family history. A film that questions the way family memories get tailored for the consumption of future generations. A study guide is available from http://www.roninfilms.com.au/related/2365104851-0.pdf
